title: first-outdoor-classroom-planned-for-east-lothian-school
story: Aberlady Primary School is set to be the first school in the county to have its own bespoke outdoors classroom built in its grounds.Overlooking the woods next to the village school, the room will be used by its nursery and will be built with timber and corrugated steelDescribed as off-grid, it will not have an electricity supply but will instead use solar  to charge a battery which will be used to power lighting in winter months.Composting toilet facilities will also be included in the plans, although they will be in a separate timber building outside the classroom.The modest classroomwill, according to plans, ldquosit quietly and comfortably within the existing grounds, providing a valuable and forward-thinking resource for the school and community of Aberlady.Applying for planning permission for the outdoors classroom, East Lothian Councilrsquos education department said that the school needed to expand its nursery provision to meet the increased hours which were being introduced.The Scottish Government wants all nursery-eligible children to be given , hours of free nursery care from August next year.A spokesperson for the local authority said that outdoor learning and classroomswere recognisedinternationally as a key development that could improve health and learning for youngsters.They said: ldquoThe proposal is for a self-contained early-years unit that is lsquooff-gridrsquo beside the schoolrsquos woodland area, which is a popular space already used by children and staff for play and outdoor learning.ldquoOnce completed,Aberladyrsquos design could act as a catalyst to developing further educational facilities across the county, offering children more opportunities to learn, play and connect with the outdoors.ldquoIngeneral terms, they [outdoor classrooms] allow children and staff the opportunity to explore their natural environment whilst also providing shelter from particularly inclement weather.ldquoChildren can gather together for snacks and group learning experiences throughout the nursery day.ldquoWe have been working with the school community and partners to develop a design that will best suit their needs.

title: north-berwick-named-in-top-10-places-to-live-in-scotland
story: Dundee came top as the best place to live in Scotland, according to the Sunday Times Best Places to Live.The study assesses a wide range of factors, from employment, schools and broadband speed to culture, community spirit and local shops.North Berwick and Dundee are the only two places in the top  which also made last years list.The other eight locations to make the list are: Leith, Edinburgh Stockbridge, Edinburgh Finnieston, Glasgow Killearn, Stirling Kilmacolm, Renfrewshire Mull Port Appin, Argyll and Bute and St Boswells, Scottish Borders.

title: hospice-residents-enjoy-virtual-reality-thanks-to-east-linton-company
story: Thanks to East Linton-based Viarama, the interactive initiative, which can virtually transport patients to locations on the other side of the world, will look at the impact of virtual realityon their health and wellbeing.An initial group of six residents at St Columbarsquos Hospice in Edinburgh benefited from the transformative effects of VR when they were offered the chance to revisit some of their favourite places or explore a part of the world they had never seen.Using the latest high-tech VR headsets, one inidual was transported to Jerusalem, a place he had always dreamed of visiting.In another session, a -year-old woman was thrilled to revisit her childhood home in Darjeeling and indulge in a trip up the Amazon river for the first time.The experience triggered happy memories with the opportunity to reminisce about old times, as well as encounter new places.The patients also took the chance to immerse themselves in an under-sea adventure.Through the use of VR, the patients could explore a sunken wreck with fish circling overhead while an enormous whale passed by.The initial virtual reality taster was run by Billy Agnew, founder of Viarama ndash said to be the worldrsquos first virtual reality social enterprise, which uses the power of VR as a force for good within communities across Scotland.He is now working along with Queen Margaret University at Musselburgh and St Columbarsquos on a research project involving  hospice patients.The project will look at the potential benefit of VR with a focus on patientsrsquo mood, pain and stress levels, as well as overall wellbeing.Mr Agnew said: ldquoWe look forward to giving many more hospice patients in Scotland the opportunity to enjoy the best VR experiences available, whilst exploring and measuring the many ways in which we believe VR helps people receiving palliative care.Dr Erna Haraldsdottir, senior lecturer in nursing at Queen Margaret University and director of education and research at St Columbarsquos Hospice, said: ldquoThanks to a grant from the Margaret Murphy Charitable Trust and generosity from Viarama, St Columbarsquos Hospice and QMU are excited to introduce a group of  patients to the exhilarating world of virtual reality at such a signicant stage in their lives.ldquoThis important research will help us better understand the benefits of using VR and identy future interventions which may improve the quality of le of patients receiving palliative care.ldquoThe patients loved it. They were thrilled by the experience.ldquoOne family member said it was the first time that her mother had smiled in months.ldquoIt was wonderful to see the immediate impact on iniduals.

title: slimming-world-weight-loss-wonder-sheds-10-stone-to-achieve-london-marathon-dream
story: Gail Tennant, , from Airdrie joined the Airdre Slimming World group in February  weighing more than st. Now she will be representing Slimming World in their national team of  slimmers from across the UK and Ireland on April th . This yearrsquos team will be the official golden Slimming World marathon team, as the organisation celebrates its th birthday year.Collectively, the team have lost more than st and will be running to raise money for Cancer Research UK and the Irish Cancer Society. The team aim to increase awareness of how keeping a healthy weight can reduce the risk of developing some types of cancer.Supporting the cancer charities is particularly important to Gail as she has seen her dad battle the disease.When first Gail joined the Airdrie Slimming World she had been running for around nine months, however struggled to get reach a certain distance with her weight and poor diet taking its toll. When she joined Slimming World, however, she found she could eat to fuel her running and lose weight at the same time.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesWhen Gail began following the Food Optimising healthy eating plan, she discovered a love for cooking. She swapped her diet of chocolate, cakes and shop-bought-sandwiches for cooking healthy, wholesome meals from scratch including her favourite dish of chicken stir fry.She said: ldquoWhen my consultant explained the eating plan, I couldnrsquot quite believe that I could lose weight without going hungry, and still enjoy all my favourite meals just by making changes to the way I prepared and cooked them. Irsquove never eaten so well in my le! And I need all the fuel I can get for marathon training ndash so potatoes, pasta, and rice are all regularly on the menu! I was so nervous before joining but I soon realised I neednrsquot have been. I got a fantastic warm welcome from the group.Gail added: ldquoI canrsquot believe Irsquom running the London Marathon after where I was a couple of years ago. Irsquove completely transformed my le, really found a love for running and canrsquot wait to be running the big one this year ndash especially in Slimming Worldrsquos golden birthday year ndash is a real dream come true!Gail said: ldquoTherersquos no way Irsquod have lost st or be running the marathon without the support of my group. They are the ones who have kept me on track each week ndash both with my weight loss and with my running milestones. My group inspired me to keep going and have been there to congratulate me whenever I reach a new lsquofurthest distancersquo, lsquofastest runrsquo and lsquohalf stone awardrsquo, as well as inspiring me with their achievements on their own journeys! Theyrsquove been really generous in sponsoring me and I know theyrsquoll be cheering me on when the day comes too!Gail started with the Couch to k app, and has now completed more than  half marathons. She canrsquot wait to run her first marathon as part of the golden Slimming World team: ldquoItrsquos so special to be on the team in Slimming Worldrsquos th birthday year. Irsquom so much happier and healthier and by losing weight I know Irsquove reduced my chances of developing a range of health problems.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesldquoI canrsquot wait for the atmosphere on race day and to cross that finish line. Achieving this dream would never have been possible before losing weight. Ilsquom excited to give something back and raise money for Cancer Research UK and the Irish Cancer Society as I have seen first-hand how the incredible research can help with treatment and help people beat cancer. Slimming World Consultant Lynn Johnston, who runs Gailrsquos weekly group sessions, says: ldquoGail is a real inspiration to us and we are all so proud of her. When she first came through the door she just wanted to lose weight ndash she had no idea what a huge le and fitness transformation she was about to begin and certainly no idea that she would one day be running the London Marathon, itrsquos incredible! She proves that with a little determination and the right support, anyonersquos dreams can be achieved.Anyone who would like to sponsor Gail and the Slimming World Marathon team can do so by visiting: justgiving slimmingworldlondonmarathonMoney raised will go towards Cancer Research UK and the Irish Cancer Societyrsquos le-saving research to help bring forward the day when all cancers are cured.If Gailrsquos story has inspired you to lose weight, everyone is welcome at the Airdre Slimming World group which is held at Springfield Community Centre, every Monday at .pm or .pm, alternatively the Airdrie group meets at St Columbarsquos Parish Church, Thrashbush Road every Thursday at .pm or .pm. For more information or to find your nearest group visit www.slimmingworld, or call   .

title: eight-councils-allocate-66m-for-redevelopment-of-former-ravenscraig-steelworks-site
story: The eight councils involved have agreed to allocate an additional pound million for the Ravenscraig Infrastructure Accessproject.City Deal cash, along with an additional pound. million from North Lanarkshire Council, will be used to upgrade roads from the M at Motherwell through Ravenscraig to the M at Eurocentral and onward past Airdrie on a new link road to the A south of Cumbernauld.The transport infrastructure project, part of the wider Pan-Lanarkshire Orbital Corridor, is vital to the overall development of the Ravenscraig site, according to councillors.They estimate the revised proposals for redeveloping Ravenscraig could create more than , jobs and boost the economy by pound million a year.: The Glasgow City Council staff paid more than pound, last yearAt  hectares, Ravenscraig is one of Europes largest brownfield regeneration sites and accounts for % of the Glasgow City Regions vacant and derelict land.Ravencraig Ltds new masterplan for the area will be considered by the council in the coming weeks and includes proposals for , houses, five primary schools, a town park and more than ,sq m of office, industrial and retail space.Paul Kelly, depute leader of North Lanarkshire Council, said: "The regeneration of Ravencraig is of major strategic and economic importance to North Lanarkshire and the wider area."The pound million Pan-Lanarkshire Orbital project represents the biggest single roads and infrastructure investment in North Lanarkshires history, and our focus must be on those projects that will attract investment to the area and be of the greatest economic benefit to our communities."Channelling our resources into creating a first-class infrastructure at Ravenscraig will bolster future investment from the private sector to create homes, businesses and job opportunities - potentially creating , jobs and generating pound million in Gross Value Addedfor the local economy."Its vital that we focus on those projects that offer the beston investment for our communities, our economy and for the future of North Lanarkshire."Speaking on BBC Good Morning Scotland, Mr Kelly added: "Theres been huge delays over the years but I really feel today is a historic day - its the biggest investment well ever see in our infrastructure and it will lead to the transformation of the Ravenscraig site."Over the last two years we have been driving this as best we can to try to transform it and to deliver on what the people of Motherwell and the wider area want on the site."Scottish Secretary David Mundell, said: "This is very welcome news and it is great to see good progress being made to the Glasgow City Region Deal.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages"The UK Government has committed more than pound million to the deal with an ambitious goal of creating jobs and opportunities and stimulating long-lasting growth for local communities."This project has the potential to transform Ravenscraig and will help to attract signicant private sector investment to bring new homes and businesses to the site."The UK Government is funding vital projects right across Scotland and to date have committed more than pound. billion to City Region and Growth Deals."Scottish Government Infrastructure Secretary Michael Matheson said: "The Scottish Government has committed to invest pound million in the Glasgow City Region Deal in pursuit of long-term, sustainable economic growth."I am pleased to see North Lanarkshire Council and the wider Glasgow City Region continue to drive this deal forward and work together in the best interests of the regional economy."

title: grannys-gone-viral-the-rise-of-the-insta-grans
story: Social media influence doesnt just belong to the young ndash its now being grasped by bloggers and Instagrammers in their seventies, eighties and beyond. Among them is Glasgows Grandma Williams who is on a mission to change the image of old age. But please, dont call her a sex blogger just because she mentions sex sometimes. That would be ageist.MORNINGS in the Grandma Williams house, a large, airy building in Glasgows Hyndland area, start at around about .. ldquoIf Irsquom lucky, David, my husband, the -year-old says, ldquobrings me a great big pot of tea and then Irsquoll stay in bed until Irsquove drunk it and then Irsquoll do all my tweeting and writing and I might not get up until .am.Joyce Williams is not a bad advert for old age in the silver surfer era. ldquoI love being in bed, she says. ldquoThe other morning I did an interview with someone from some paper. I was lying in bed with my pot of tea and my night dress ndash they didnrsquot know I was doing that. Thatrsquos what you do when yoursquore old. You donrsquot have to get up. You can choose what you want to do. You can say Irsquom not stuffing doing that. Itrsquos a lovely feeling.Itrsquos mid-morning now on a Thursday, and, over coffee, Williams is putting the world bang to rights. The pensions time bomb, ageism in the work place, the myth of the old as generation lonely, are all issues she tackles. When I ask her how wersquore going to sort all that out, she eyeballs me. ldquoIrsquod like to make this a challenge to you. How are you going to get it sorted for your generation  This is your problem.She writes about such issues, and others, in her regular Grandma Williams blog, in posts with provocative, upbeat headlines. ldquoGetting the buzz at + Not a minister for loneliness ndash letrsquos have one for excitement. ldquoSex at   Sex at   Of course! ldquoRed carpet at ! What to wear  ldquoStereotyping of oldies  Stupid!One of her concerns, as we chat, is over the struggle that current midlers are going to have when we meet old age, in huge numbers, and find we have no pensions really to speak of, are in the grip of an obesity crisis, and also,current trends continue, struggle to get jobs because of ageism in the workplace.ldquoI really want to challenge your generation to stop and think. We fought for these things ndash and yoursquore threatening to lose them. Your pension rights and health gains are going backwards. We made enormous health gains. People died on average at . Now its . Yoursquore going to have to tackle the obesity issue - thatrsquos your problem."What really are the granters wishes  Stories of power of attorneyFar from disappearing into her sunset years, she is gaining the kind of social media following many a millennial would envy. Williams, a former physiotherapist, is part of a growing trend ndash the older social media influencer, sometimes called the Instagrans or Insta-grandmas. They include, for instance, -year-old Swede, Dagny Valborg Carlsson, who started blogging after she did a class on computing at the age of , and -year-old Eileen Smith from Ireland, always elegant, with bouffant hair swept back in a bun, in Instagram posts that have have garnered a following of k. Like most of her ilk, Smith espouses a carefree, outward-looking attitude. She has said she keeps a note by her bed that urges, "Get up, dress up, get out and donrsquot look back."Possibly most famous is Baddiewinkle, a -year-old American Instagrammer with grey-haired rebel attitude, whose account sports the tagline ldquostealing your man since . This former factory-worker and farmer, whose real name is Helen Ruth Elam Van Winkle, began her social media career after her great-granddaughter took a photograph of her sunbathing in the garden, whilst wearing cut-off denim shorts, a rainbow tie-dye T-shirt and neon-pink marijuana leaf print socks. She now has . million followers.Williams seems a youngster by comparison. Blogging is something she fell into almost by accident, as a way of making new friends after she had moved, at the age of , to Glasgow where her husband David, whom she had married six years earlier, had a home. ldquoI saw this sign, saying, Blogging for beginners," she recalls. "Irsquom always curious about things and I thought, I donrsquot actually know what a blog is but itrsquos writing and I love writing.When she turned up she found the oldest, apart from her, was a -year-old. Most were in their thirties. When the class leaders told her she should find a topic, she struggled. ldquoThen they said, Well why donrsquot you write about being old  Theyrsquod been so interested in what Irsquod been saying to them. Theyrsquod not really talked to an old person before. That was when I started to think that I really wanted to get across this idea that the image of old age is wrong. Itrsquos not like the media say. Itrsquos not so grim. I wanted to balance the mediarsquos doom and gloom. I thought, I will post the positives that the media doesnrsquot publish.Several years on, Williams is still all about the positives. Not only does she believe that she is happier now than almost any other stage in her le, but she believes the course of history has made things better for most people. ldquoI do think the world has got better. The quote I love is that Louis XIV, the Sun King, had  chefs, he could have a choice of  dishes at his meals. We can go into Tesco and get . We are richer than the Sun King ndash the average person.She tells tales from her own youth, growing up in industrial South Yorkshire, which put our current woes in perspective. Her grandmother was so poor that when she got ill in old-age she was cared for in the local workhouse ndash but Williams now, she observes, like many her age, has a nice pension. Le expectancy has enormously extended. She says shersquod like to get together with a few young women now to talk about how bad it was back then.ldquoAttitudes around abortion and homosexuality and contraception were so dreadful. There was this whole disapproval of bastardy in my childhood. My best friend got pregnant at university. She had to go into a home to have the baby. It was given away for adoption. Never saw it again. She would have made a wonderful mother. It wasnrsquot okay to be a single parent then. It was a scandal.#MeToo, meanwhile, is something she doesnt "understand". "What is it ," she says. "Itrsquos all this I was abused as a kid. But we all were. It was normal. We learned to laugh. There was a flasher who turned up at our school gate most lunchtimes and we all had a wander down to have a giggle. You just learned to laugh. We didnrsquot take it seriously. We werenrsquot harmed by it."What she wanted to be, she decided, when she wrote a business plan for her blog, was a ldquonational ageing influencer - a go-to person about ageing. ldquoIrsquove done that, she says. ldquoThere are other influencers out there, Charlotte Rampling, Joan Bakewell, Helen Mirren, but theyrsquore famous for dferent reasons. They havenrsquot got there from being just an old person, with no other reason to be famous.Many of the older people causing a sensation on Instagram are those that seem to bust stereotypes in some sort of outrageous way, by wearing flamboyant outfits, saying shocking things or by doing some extraordinary feat. Lili Hayes, in the United States ndash Instagram bio "always a little pissed ndash has won over k followers for her posts in which she is seen dressed in streetwear, sporting a signature Supreme cap, while making faces or working out to Nicki Minajrsquos Anaconda.Or there are the wild risk-takers, like Dilys Price, who set the world record for the oldest female parachute jump, a long-term blogger on her own website, who only just joined Instagram, declaring ldquoI am one of the few octogenarians now on Instagram at  years young!But Williams isnrsquot about such extremes. She doesnrsquot think you needed to be ing out of an aeroplane or running an ultrathon to prove that your late years can be lived well. ldquoYou donrsquot need to go skying, she says. ldquoYou can doyou wish. But all you need to do is get yourself out the house and go for a walk, with a dog, or look at the flowers. Le is great. There is no need to be excessively fit. Therersquos a lot of research now on the need to do some weight-training. She shuffles in her chair and begins doing some push ups. ldquoI do it in this arm chair. Donrsquot need to go to a gym.Why does she think her blog has worked  ldquoIrsquove worked very hard at it. Its only been two and a half years and Irsquove written way over a hundred blogs. Irsquove tweeted every morning for all of that time. Irsquove done a lot of research into ageing and every time Irsquove found an interesting blog about ageing and ageism, Irsquove tweeted it with comments. Irsquove explored the internet and found anybody who is an influencer in ageing and Irsquove always sent them my blogs.Of those hundred plus blogs, three of her posts have got her more publicity than anything  ndash landing her, for instance, on television, being interviewed by Philip Schofield on This Morning. These three, though a fraction of her output, have had her labelled, across the media, as a sex blogger or sexpert ndash and itrsquos to this that she objects. Yes, they were about sex but that doesnt make her a sex blogger. The way she has been labelled is, she says, is a kind of voyeuristic ageism in itself.ldquoA respectable professional woman with an MBE, chair of a national society, being labelled Grandma Williams sex blogger  They wouldnrsquot have done thatit were you, a woman in your forties. No one would pick it up and make a headline and invite you to speak on television with Philip Schofield.The first of these posts was written because of the conversations she was having with other people on her workshop. Some, she recalls, were writing dating advice blogs. ldquoOne of them in particular, was pretty frank, about how to do a good blow job, and they were talking about this and they were looking at me, thinking is it all right to talk about this in front of her. I thought, hang on a minute! Irsquove had  years more experience than you of sex. I do know what a blow job is. I realised that it was something that needed to be said, because that was again part of the image of old age, that we just stop having sex when wersquore over .Williams also sees plenty of people in her age group enjoying late-le romances ndash including some friends of hers who she says are like ldquoblooming lovebirds ndash canrsquot put each other down. In her seventies, she had her own such romance. Her husband David was someone she had known for decades, through his we, who also was a physiotherapist. ldquoI came to this house when they first got married,  years ago. And then my husband died and eventually she died, so we got together."Irsquove got Scotland rooting for me, which is really special ndash Glasgow makeup vlogging sensation Jamie GenevieveUnlike Grandma Williams many of the most popular influencers are style icons in some way and find their biggest impact on Instagram, where they, like younger influencers, also attract big brands who want to work with them. For instance, one of the most followed older Instagrammers in England is Suzi Grant, a nutritionist, former television presenter and author of books, including Alternative Ageing. When, in her sixties, she found herself bored, her two god-daughters both, separately, suggested she start blogging.Her Alternative Ageing blog is a fusion of style-advice, health tips and general wisdom about living well. She has around , followers on Instagram, half of which are under the age of . Like Williams she beams positivity.ldquoIrsquom a very cup half full person, she says. Though shersquos all about the style ndash a vintage look incorporating s hair bangs and endless headscarves ndash she also comes across as care-free and not too bothered about her wrinkles or saggy bits. ldquoWersquove all got body dysmorphia, havenrsquot we  But, Irsquove got over it.For her, the blog, is absolutely ldquonot about fashion. Itrsquos about style. ldquoI donrsquot do just fashion and I think thatrsquos why itrsquos been successful. My blog is about how you feel. Irsquove always said right from the beginning that I want women to look good but feel great. I think feeling great is far more important than the looking good. If yoursquore really healthy and you exercise and lead a really full happy le, then just dressing up a bit more can make the dference between walking out the door feeling invisible and walking out the door feeling really happy."One of the things, she says, that worries her is how few posts there are on UK Instagram with the hashtag #over or #styleover, by comparison with the equivalents in younger decades. ldquoItrsquos really bad. Irsquove got a huge job to do. Itrsquos not a problem in America, there are masses of influencers over , even over . In fact, itrsquos very popular there and there are loads of bloggers in those categories as well as older people who have become famous because of the way they dress.Grant is referring to what is sometimes called Advanced Style, a movement celebrating style in older women that was partly triggered by the blogs of Ari Seth Cohen, and the book and documentary that followed. She cites Seth Cohen as her inspiration. ldquoWatching the Advanced Style documentary started the whole thing for me. I now know him. Hersquos a personal friend of mine. But he thinks I look too young still for his blogs, which is really distressing. He took a picture and looked at the camera and said, lsquoYoursquore still too young.rsquo He wants them with really grey hair. And also I donrsquot think Irsquom outrageous enough.Grant says that this is one of the happiest periods of her le. ldquoIrsquom doing everything that Irsquove always loved doing in a career without any of the stress.This emphasis on happiness is something she shares with Joyce Williams, who says she believes that for many the years over  are the happiest in their lives. This, she says, is backed up by statistics, by what she calls the graph of happiness which peaks at around  years old ldquoand stays high."I was quite suicidal at  years old, she says. ldquoSeriously suicidal. That was because I lost my husband at that point to cancer and wersquod only been married two years. I wasnrsquot a really confident teenager or young woman either. But Irsquove always had a curious mind."I think it surprised me how happy you are over . I didnrsquot realise what a good le it is until I got there and all my friends all said the same thing. People say, Are you worried about dying  No, Irsquom happy to die. Irsquove done everything I was going to do. I live day to day somehow. Itrsquos more serene. Itrsquos a bit like meditation in some ways, you get more serene, more adjusted to le.

title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: applicants-wanted-for-once-in-a-lifetime-opportunity-to-live-at-remote-lighthouse-to-record-whales
story: Now two people are wanted for a ldquoonce in a letime experience of watching the waters for a living at Ardnamurchan Lighthouse as part of efforts to record migrating whales.The summer placements at the remote lighthouse are aimed at developing the Hebridean Whale Trail, which launches soon and will be the first of its kind inthe UK.The trail will be a network of about world-class whale-watching and whale heritage sites, developed by the Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust .It plans to promote Scotland as oneof Europersquos best destinations for spotting whales, dolphins and porpoisesndash collectively known as cetaceans ndash and champion conservation of the Hebridesrsquo unique, globally important marine wildle and environment.And the trust is looking for a couple willing to turn their backs on urban living and keep an eye out for passing whales and dolphins in the area.The job is voluntary but food, accommodation and all expenses willbe met by the trust for theofthe project.:Scotlands only resident killer whale colony faces extinction due to illegal chemicals in the seaIts leaders say successful candidates must provide ldquoexpert wildle guiding and informal interpretation to visitors about Hebridean marine wildle, environment and heritage and ldquocarry out dedicated land-based cetacean data collection and encourage visitors to participate in whale watching and biological recording activities.The job description adds: ldquoAre you looking to gain valuable work experience, and play an active role in marine conservation  Are you interested in living and working at a lighthouse in a remotebut beautul part of Scotland  If so, then this is a fantastic opportunity for a once in a letime experience.ldquoThe Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust has been leading the way for the conservation of cetaceans in the Hebrides for  years.ldquoAs the trusted voice and primary source of information in the region, HWDT research has critically advanced the understanding of Scotlandrsquos whales, dolphins and porpoises while working directly with communities to encourage the stewardship of our rich seas.It says the post offers ldquothe opportunity to be a part of a project which will connect communities and visitors with the amazing Hebridean marine environment, adding: ldquoThe Ardnamurchan Lighthouse Trust operates a busy visitor centre and cafe, offering the chance to learn more about Scottish lighthouses, and the flora and fauna of the Ardnamurchan peninsula.ldquoThe volunteer will be responsible for the delivery of the Hebridean Whale Trailrsquos Ardnamurchan programme, working with members of the HWDT team alongside Ardnamurchan Lighthouse staff.ldquoLiving and working at a lighthouse ina remote but beautul part of Scotland makes this is a fantastic opportunity for a once in a letime experience, while playing an active part in marine conservation.A quarter of the worldrsquos whale and dolphin speciesrsquo live off the Scottish coast, making it one of the best European destinations to try and catch a glimpseof cetaceans.Bottlenose dolphins, rissorsquos and common dolphins, harbour porpoises, minke whales, humpbacks and killer whales are all found in Hebridean seas.Tiumpan Head, on Lewis, is also considered the best place in Europe tosee cetaceans from land all year round.Wildle tourism is becoming big business in Scotland, with whale-watching top of many peoplersquos list.Other denizens of the deep have also become hits on the tourist trail, with a company that specialises in swimming with basking sharks being awarded a five-star rating from VisitScotland last month.Basking Shark Scotland received the national tourism bodyrsquos top grading at the first time of asking after a bumper year that saw the company fully booked during the peak summer season.The Oban-based firm offers trips tosee basking sharks in their natural environment and swim alongside them using a snorkel or scuba gear.The wildle tour company was awarded the five-star rating from VisitScotlandrsquos Quality Assurance Scheme in recognition of its exceptional standards. It also wonthe Best Outdoor Experience title at the Highlands  Islands Tourism Awards.Founded by marine biologist Shane Wasik in , Basking Shark Scotland also offers seal-swimming tours, sea-bird safaris, and beach-cleaning trips toisolated islands.Meanwhile, Calmac Ferries launcheda new national marketing campaignahead of this yearrsquos tourism season toraise awareness of Uist as an ldquounmissable getaway.Although the two islands have fewer than , residents, they are home to remarkable wildle such as golden eagles, wading birds and otters.

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: MARCH-mad Yessers All Under One Banner have been bigging up their first outing of the season. "Wersquore hoping to [get] over , people, gushed one organiser about their May  parade in Glasgow. That doesnrsquot seem to tally with what they told the city council. The official list of future processions states: ldquoEstimated number of participants ,. Fancy that.Graphic noveltyTALKING of dodgy numbers, Unspun was struck by Tory posters in Thursdayrsquos Leith Walk by-election in Edinburgh. These featured a bar chart suggesting the party could win as it came first at the last election on %. Well, sort of. That was the citywide figure in . In Leith Walk the Tories came fourth on %. On Thursday, they came fourth on %. Put that on your next bar chart, why donrsquot you.Recycling projectAMONG those campaigning for the SNP in the ward was former MP Angus Robertson, who is eyeing Ruth Davidsonrsquos Edinburgh Central seat for the  Holyrood election. His interest is seen by some as Nicola Sturgeon teeing up her old pal as her successor. Those who fancy the FMs job are unimpressed, not least with the optics of parachuting in a Westminster loser to save the day at Holyrood. Miaow.Cherry blossomsOTHERS think the Nat to watch is Edinburgh MP Joanna Cherry QC, who is also tilting at Ms Davidsonrsquos constituency, where she is being punted by ex-MSP Marco Biagi. With her forensic questioning over Brexit, Ms Cherry is on a roll at Westminster right now. So why go to Holyrood  ldquoAh, says our mole, ldquobecause the leader of the party has to be an MSP. Gulp.Volume controlGREEN MSP Andy Wightman set a hare running in  when he told Holyrood some Edinburgh residents endured ldquovery audible sex parties from short-term lets next door. An intrepid citizen has now used FoI to ask the city council how many complaints it had about ldquoloud sex noises from the neighbours. An arid reply this week said the request fell into the category of ldquomanestly unreasonable and the council was not obliged to respond. Moreover, it would take officials  hours to comb the data. Which would be an indoor marathon too far.Money manTHE prospect of a general election is making party beancounters jumpy. The Tories are skint and Labourrsquos not much better off. As for the SNP  Donations ainrsquot what they used to be, Unspun hears. Apart from membership fees, the Nats gets most of their cash from taxpayers - via Westminster short money - bequests, and the odd small business. Remarkably, their biggest living donor last year was Glasgow MSP John Mason, on the basis of just pound.Little VoiceFINALLY, more news from the SNPrsquos ever-feuding North Lanarkshire outfit. After the partyrsquos top councillor was ousted by his deputy, there has been a purge of the old guard, many of whom were loyal to Coatbridge MSP Fulton MacGregor. So farewell councillors Carragher, Stocks, Stubbs and Larson, all of whom were axed as permanent members of the powerful Policy and Strategy Committee. Mr MacGregor boasted at the  Holyrood election he would be ldquostrong voice. Alas, not strong enough to save his cronies.

title: the-issue-of-the-week-assisted-dying-legislation
story: :Study links Glasgow HIV outbreak to surge in homelessness and addicts injecting cocaineWhat is the assisted dying bill The End of Le Assistance Bill was first proposed to Holyrood by MSP Margo MacDonald, who lived with Parkinsons Disease, in . It was defeated but she brought it back to the table in , a year before she died.The law that Dignity in Dying Scotland campaign for would allow terminally ill, mentally competent adults the option to request le-ending medication from a doctor. Numerous safeguards are proposed, including two independent doctors confirming that the inidual met all the necessary criteria and was making a clear and settled decision free of coercion.Any decision would have to be signed off by a High Court judge and the inidual could rescind their request at any time, and are under no obligation to take the medicationit is eventually granted.The medication must be self-administered, so that the entire process is controlled by the inidual ndash another important safeguard.Whyis it needed A third attempt at passing the bill in Scotland has been launched in response to changing public moods after high profile cases including Noel Conway who lost his legal challenge at the UK court of appeal in . After his fight to die "peacefully and with dignity" was rejected, Mr Conway, who has motor neurone disease, called on politicians to change the law.Mr Conway, from Shrewsbury, said: "It is downright cruel to continue to deny me and other terminally-ill people this right."It is currently a criminal offence to assist a suicide and can hold a sentence of up to  years.:Hospital confirms third baby died of rare blood infectionWhat are people saying A group of cross-party MSPs have come out against the fresh call opposing politicians including Kezia Dugdale, Patrick Harvie and Jackson Carlaw in an open letter to The Sunday Times newspaper. Scottish Tory deputy leader Murdo Fraser is one of the nine objectors along with Labours Elaine Smith and the SNPs John Mason. They said that legalising assisted dying was"the measure of a desperately cold, soulless society. We think that in Scotland today we are better than that."The National writes that Carlaw, Harvie, Dugdale and six other MSPs supported the call after careful thought and considered debate.They said: ldquoThe uncomfortable truth is that we are failing the people we met in Parliament this week. We cannot go on pretending the status quo is acceptable ndash it is not.Heather McQueen from Dalkeith whose mother died of cancer in supports the new campaign. She said: ldquoMy mumrsquos name was Sheena. She was a school teacher. She was a wise, witty, strong woman. She had a really, really god le but she had a really bad death.ldquoMy mum had anal cancer. The last week was really, really horric. She did receive palliative care in the hospital but it just couldnrsquot control her pain and we could do nothing but wait for her to die. The nurses would come round and askthey could do anything for her and she would raise her two fingers to her temple, in the manner of a gun, to signy that the main thing they could do for her would be to let her go.ldquoHad assisted dying been legal, my mum would not have ended her le in that completely unnecessarily cruel way.Ally Thomson, Director of Dignity in Dying Scotland said: ldquoWhat is clear from our polling and the reaction wersquove had to our campaign so far, is that the people of Scotland are firmly behind a change in the law to allow dying people a real say over their death. Scots evidently understand that terminally people and their families are suffering under the current system and they will not stand for it.ldquoAt the heart of this campaign is love. The people I speak to who want the choice of an assisted death love their le. They donrsquot want to die, but they are terminally ill. They simply want the right to die as well as possible, and to live their le to the full, with those they love, right to the end assisted dying would give them that. Irsquove spoken to others who have lost beloved partners, parents or siblings and are haunted by memories of their traumatic, drawn-out deaths. These people were forced to look on, helpless, as those closest to them suffered. They are desperate to help ensure that no other family has to go through what they have."Whats next Dignity in Dying are asking supporters to sign an official online register for assisted dying at www.letsdotherightthing.org.

title: by-election-success-spurs-hopes-scottish-greens-can-oust-ukip-in-bid-for-first-mep
story: SNP candidate Rob Munn won the Leith Walk ward from Labour, but the largest swing in the vote saw the Greens come second, pushing Labour into third.Green candidate Lorna Slater won .% of first preference votes - up .% from  -  behind the SNP, although the gap narrowed to  votes in the final round of the count.Scottish Green Party co-convener Patrick Harvie said the result gives him confidence that the party can secure its first MEP at the European Parliament elections in May.Mr Harvie said: "The result in Leith Walk is a tremendous lt for Greens ahead of European elections and huge credit goes to the brilliant Lorna Slater who ran a superb campaign."Its clear that theres strong support for our inspiring vision for rebuilding democracy, locally and across Europe, so that we can tackle the climate crisis, lt people out of poverty and create a welcoming society which rejects far-right populism."At the last European elections, Greens narrowly missed out on our first Scottish MEP to an extremist Ukip candidate whose campaign was flooded with cash and who was given a hugely disproportionate media ."By making the positive case for Scotlands place in Europe, were determined that wont happen again."The UK looks set to participate in the European elections following the six-month extension to Article  granted by the EU.Earlier this week, the UK Government tabled an order enabling elections to the European Parliament to be held in Britainthe country has not left the EU by the time they take place next month.The Day of Poll Order sets the date for the elections on May , but the Cabinet Office said they would automatically be cancelledthe UK left before then.European elections are held every five years, with the UK electing  MEPs to sit in the -member Parliament in Brussels and Strasbourg.Scotland elects six MEPs through proportional representation and in the  election two SNP and two Labour representatives were chosen along with one Conservative and one Ukip MEP.

title: scottish-mothers-share-their-home-birth-experiences-as-meghan-markle-prepares-for-hers
story: Now the couple are preparing for the birth of baby number five and their third to be born in the comfort of their home.Four years ago, Mrs Gray was apprehensive about the birth of son Lauchlan after two ldquostraightforward but dramatic births in hospital. Living in Pitlochry, she was also concerned about the distance to the hospital in Perth, so she started researching alternatives.She said: ldquoThe evidence I was looking at suggested it was safer for me to have a home birth as my risk factors were really low.:Only two in  mothers in Scotland having a home birth - but NHS Tayside records -fold increaseAfter a seamless birth with Lauchlan at home, it was an easy decision to do it again two years later with daughter, Vaila, who was delivered in just  minutes.Mrs Gray said:Lauchlan had never been away from me before. It meant he didnrsquot need to be separated from us and then brought back in to a little interloper in the house. And for the older boys as well, just the continuity of taking away that disruption.That her husband could stay after the birth and keep himself busy during labour when he was not needed was another bonus. She said: ldquoHe was able to support me with our baby without having to leave at the end of visiting time.ldquoThere was no feeling of being rushed, it was all very relaxed and calm. I felt in control of what was happening. It was my space so I could call the shots.Mrs Gray, , was so comfortable in her own surroundings, she needed no pain relief. She said: ldquoIt was painful but I was in control. I think when you start to panic, or you feel out of control, thatrsquos when the pain becomes something you canrsquot cope with. My first two births were more painful than my last two.So good was the care she received she believes it would rival that of the Duchess of Sussex, Meghan Markle, and Prince Harry arereported to be planning to have their firstbaby at home.Mrs Gray said: ldquoItrsquos not just something celebrities or royals can do with a huge amount of resources at their disposal, the NHS provides the same level of really good care. You have two midwives with you all the time and they are monitoring you so closely.Gemma Nealon is an NHS midwe, co-founder of Birth Trauma Scotland and runs Positive Birth Scotland. She also teaches midwives and student midwives at Edinburgh Napier University and with NHS Lothian and has attended more than  home births.Ms Nealon firmly believes the traditional culture of fear surrounding birth needs to be change, which is one of the reasons she chose to have her daughters at home. She said: ldquoFrom what I knew of the physiology of birth, I just thought it was where I would be the most relaxed and calm.She went on to have ldquounbelievable births that left her feeling ldquofabulous.From her professional background, Ms Nealon knows fear ldquois not conducive to childbirth.She said: ldquoThe culture around birth needs to be changed. Itrsquos always scary birth stories that are shared and that can become a self-fulfilling prophecy becauseyou do go into hospital in such a state of fear often you have a longer labour because you are actually slowing it down with this ongoing fight or flight response.A home birth is not suitable for everyone, whether through choice or circumstance but it doesnrsquot have to be stressful, Ms Nealon said. She recommends labouring for as long as possible at home so the hormones that promote calmness can have a chance to kick in. She said: ldquoBirth is so natural and instinctive . Our bodies are incredible machines that do what they have to do.:Back to the Future: Will home births ever become the norm again Mother-of-two Bekki Robinson, , endured a traumatic birth with her first daughter during a five day labour where she was induced then wheeled in for an emergency caesarean before her baby was pulled out with forceps. She said: ldquoIt was very stressful and hospital for me was a very frightening place.Pregnant with her second daughter a year later, she attended the Edinburgh Positive Birth Scotland workshops and realised she could do it dferently this time. She said: ldquoIt just totally changed my thought process around birth because you hear negative birth stories all the time and I discovered you could have a positive experienceyou take control and learn about the process of childbirth.Her two births were like ldquoday and night with her new-found knowledge and confidence. She said: ldquoI knew what my body needed. I knew when to sleep and I even cooked during labour as a way to relax. I just felt totally empowered.ldquoYou need to be in your most relaxed state [to give birth]. And I didnrsquot have that in a hospital.Giving birth at home by candlelight meant she was able to pull her daughter out and nurse her almost immediately. She said: ldquoIt was a real Lion King moment ... it all felt very primal.ANALYSISDr Jenny Patterson is a research fellow at Edinburgh Napier University and recently completed a PHD in birth trauma and post traumatic stress disorder. She has worked in the NHS and as an independent midwe. She writes:"The news the Duchess of Sussex is planning a home birth is a very positive thing. Having worked as an independent midwe, and as a mother who has had two children, Irsquom strongly in support of a home birth in the right circumstances."My research has shown itrsquos the womenrsquos subjective experience of what happens to her thatrsquos the most important thing. A woman can go through obstetric interventions in a hospital environment or she could go through a lovely home water birth and either of those births could be traumatised, depending on how they perceived that experience."A huge amount of research, initiated by government, shows continuity of care anddeveloping trusting relationships with midwives is hugely beneficial in terms of outcomes, both physical and psychological. There is a five-year plan working towards that ndash and within that therersquos a greater scope for supporting home births."Feeling safe is the key thing and some women feel much safer in hospital because they know theyrsquove got the support. That peace of mind makes a huge dference. For others, being at home is where they feel most safe and secure and that will facilitate the chance of a better birth outcome."Butwe want this to work well for women, we need the staff to be supported and enabled to give that care. At the moment, the pressures on staff, the under-resourcing, the lack of access to as much training as some of the staff would like to follow up on, these things make it very dficult."Ultimately, what I support is womenrsquos choice because itrsquos important to recognise home birth isnrsquot always right for every woman. Itrsquos up to women to be supported in the route they choose would be best for them to have their babies."The system has to be structured in such a way that becomes a real option for women. The new NHS models, Best Start In Scotland and Better Births in England are working towards making that a real possibility and thatrsquos a very positive and exciting change."

title: why-the-2018-heatwave-was-the-last-straw-for-scotlands-farmers
story: Scottish farmers were not long in to last year when they realised they had less straw, and that the stalks they did have were shorter than usual.They had suffered a wet autumn in , hitting their winter crops, before a big winter and spring freeze and a scorching, grass-drying summer.The result  Their animals had less grass to eat in the summer and so needed more cut feed, such as straw. But the farmers had less straw.  was, literally, the year Scottish farmers pulled a short straw.Add to this increased demand for the product for power generation and animal bedding. The price of straw soared over the winter of -, from about pound a tonne to pound or even pound.The World Wildle Fund this week published a detailed report in to additional costs facing farmers in . They incited another report suggesting a hypothetical upland beef farm with a typical  cows faced extra costs of around pound, due to higher straw use. That is because the cows were inside longer and eating more and increasingly expensive straw.The WWF Scotland report stressed Scottish farmers sometimes struggled to get straw from northern England, which was also hit by bad weather in autumn . It reported some farmers getting straw ldquofrom as far as Kent. It added: ldquoThese distant supplies incurred additional transport costs.Consumers care about the price in the shops of their beef, lamb or bread. Nobody outside farming thinks about straw, or tastierand greener hay.But Scotlandrsquos increasingly changing climate means policy-makers are going to have to start thinking about the yellow stuff. The National Farmers Union Scotland last summer responded with a long campaign to get members to think about where their straw and other feed was going to come from. Farmers, they said, should plan ahead and have a back up plan in case their usual supply proves insufficient. And they should consider pooling buying power with neighbours.NFUS President Andrew McCornick said: ldquoUnpredictable weather could become more prevalent and the union is looking to encourage farmers to think further ahead and to plan for these challenges.

title: herald-diary-cooking-the-books-with-sheep-dip
story: SEEING the spring lambs in the fields reminds us of a few farm stories that have appeared in The Diary, including the reader who assured us that farmers of a dram would buy generous quantities of the smooth blended malt whisky Sheep Dip and put it through the farms books as a tax and VAT deductible expense.Prince baled outWE also liked the great story of Prince Philip, told to us by a Bearsden reader, who said: "When we lived in Windsor in the sixties my father was a part-time fireman. The brigade was called to a fire at Home Farm on the Windsor Castle Estate. To prevent it spreading the firemen climbed up and down a ladder removing bales of hay two at a time. Prince Philip came to help. He was then challenged as to why he was only carrying one hay bale instead of two. His reply was because you lot are being paid to do this and I am doing it for fun!rsquo"Quacked itA BBC programme which celebrated the old teatime telly magazine programme Nationwide, reminded a Glasgow-based former BBC man of when he worked on the show in the early s. A film of a skateboarding duck was a big hit on the programme, so the hunt was on to find other unusual ducks. When a farmer in Norfolk phoned to say he had the oldest duck in Britain, a film crew rushed to his farm only, said our reader, to career into the farmyard, drive straight over the aforementioned duck and flatten it.Write answerA READER once told us about his six-year-old daughter having to write the traditional what-I-did-on-my-holidays essay on her first week back at school. Reading it over, he expressed his surprise that she had chosen to write about a rain-soaked day at a farm park at Ayr rather than their glorious sun-filled family fortnight in the Canary Islands. She merely replied that Ayr was easier to spell than Fuerteventura.Herd instinctA GARAGE manager told us that a customer brought in his car which had two side  bashed in, and told the mechanic that he was driving in the country when it was hit by "a herd of horses". The mechanic looked puzzled and told him: "Herd of horses  Is it not a herd of cows " But the customer replied: "Naw, it was definitely horses.Cluck thatPETER Kerr, who wrote about running a farm in Majorca in his book Snowball Oranges, reminisced with us that the old Majorcan farmer across the road once offered to sweep their clogged chimney. Said Peter: "He arrived with a ladder and a sack containing his chimney-sweeping apparatus, and emptied contents of sack down the chimney. There was much noise from up the lum, heaps of soot came tumbling down, followed by the apparatus - a live hen. It worked a treat, and the hen just shook off the soot, clucked indignantly, and wandered back over the lane.

title: paul-tamburrini-theres-dignity-in-it-and-dignity-is-what-our-people-need-to-get-their-lives-back-on-track
story: The Glaswegian, who runs Paul Tamburrini at Macdonald Holyrood Hotel, in Edinburgh, sources his daily bread from an unusual bakery in his home city."Its wicked," he says enthusiastically. "To be honest, we would struggle to make that quality of bread day in, day out. It has a beautul crust and the textures are just incredible. It just gives you peace of mind that they deliver quality at all times. Matt," he adds, "is just so inspirational. Hes a lovely man, just awesome. Hes got a nice way about him ... unlike, he says with a quick laugh, ldquous chefs."The artisan bread comes from an operation located in Unit E of Rosemount Business Park. Freedom Bakery, its called. . And the Matt  That would be Matt Fortune, a -year-old social entrepreneur.Four years ago Fortune established the bakery at HMP Low Moss, in Bishopbriggs. It was a bold step in all sorts of ways. At first it was a small operation, training prisoners in the exacting art of making artisan bread, and selling the produce to city restaurants and cafes. In , having decided to expand properly, Fortune opened purpose-built premises in the business park. The move was realised via funding from the social-investment charity, Resilient Scotland, and from nearly pound, crowdfunding, which was raised in just  days.Today, the bakery has a staff of , a quarter of whom are former prisoners, and who work under the direction of professional bakers. Its wholesale menu ranges from wholemeal or ryeberry sourdough to croissants, pain au chocolate, brioche buns and baguettes. Fresh bread is supplied not just to Tamburrinis kitchens in Edinburgh but also to Gamba, the Ubiquitous Chip, The Ox  Finch, and Crabshaak in Glasgow. They are among  businesses that have accounts with Freedom.In addition to the ex-prisoners on the staff, the bakery offers day-release training programmes to prisoners from Greenock, Barlinnie and Low Moss. And, where it can, it seeks to offer jobs to its trainees once their sentences come to an end.For this is the point of Freedom Bakery: its a social enterprise that believes that people who are at risk of committing crime can benefit signicantly from professional training and job opportunities. It bridges the gap between being in custody and suddenly regaining freedom, and maintains a continuity for such people at a time "when nearly everything  about their lives," it says, "is chaotic."Fountain points out that . per cent of prisoners in Scotland commit another crime within a year of being released, but that a prisoner who finds work is  per cent less likely toto prison. A recent report by a Commons Select Committee at Westminster said that re-offending in England and Wales costs an estimated pound billion a year. Put these figures together and you can see the advantages of small but thriving ventures like this bakery.The business is open to every category of prisoner, except those who have committed sex crimes, or crimes involving children. It mostly works with inmates serving sentences of four years or more. Some have done time for fraud, others for drug-related offences. Some have spent most of their le behind bars. Some have physical disabilities, or mental health issues, or are recovering from addictions.The bakery has also paid for therapy for some employees and in a number of cases has helped place a deposit down for a home to rent.Prisoners can get placements here while they are serving their sentence. "For some prisoners, when they are in the last year of their sentence, as part of the rehabilitation process theyre given the opportunity to go out of the prison on day release," says Fortune, . "For the prison, its primarily about risk, and seeing that the person be trustworthy and not run away."Actually, its a great opportunity to meet someone while theyre still in prison, part of - for want of a better word - a captive market and try and bring them round to the sort of hard-line outcomes that makes someone employable and able to do a job, but, more than that, getting them used to the stresses and strains of a fully ing bakery and being part of the team."All of that goes with a job that you and I experience every day but for some of these people, who have literally never had a job, its a bit more dficult. But its also more rewarding."A lot of research - policy and criminological - shows thatyou can form a relationship with someone while theyre still in prison, and maintain that relationship once they leave, the likelihood of them reoffending is greatly diminished, and the likelihood of them changing their le for the better is all the more assured."So the relationship changes," he continues, "and they become employees of ours, on the same pay-scale as everyone  in the bakery. Eventually, people move on, but its not something we push necessarily. You could see that there might be a problem in a couple of years when we have too many employees and not enough work or capacity, so were trying to develop a way of starting up people in very low capital-intensive businesses, jobs, which we fund and in which that person is able to make his own cash."Fortune stresses that these plans have still to be finalised, and says its only because the bakery has been "quite successful that we feel confident that we can slowly but surely expand that business to be able to do this."Back in December , when the Low Moss bakery was but a few months old, Fortune told a reporter from this paper that he had recruited his team of prisoners by placing adverts in the halls where they lived, then issuing application forms. One inmate had already developed a walnut and rye bread, which was proving remarkably popular. .Fortune acknowledges that the Scottish Prison Service was more than happy to work with him at Low Moss. "The honest truth is that this came about because the SPS wanted it to happen. Unfortunately, Ive no powers of lobbying or of understanding the politics, which are very bureaucratic and fraught. So this really did come from them. It was always an experiment for them, and I guess it was an experiment for me, because I had never done anything with food before, never done anything with criminal justice."Its a miracle that it ever survived, and flourished. But here we are. Were still going, still learning many lessons, but with a little bit more breathing space than we used to have."Were there any models that he looked to when he was setting up at Low Moss  "Not really. I did look at a bakery in Italy [San Patrignano, which works with recovering drug addicts], but that was more for inspiration:they could get recovering drug addicts to do amazing things, why couldnt this happen where  I looked at the Clink charity, which runs restaurants inside prisons in England and Wales. Its really impressive, and I guess that had a great deal of influence on me when I was starting out. But as with so many things, you dont know what youre really doing until youre actually doing it."Wrongly or rightly, one of the things that I was quite passionate about was to not be publicly funded. One reason was reputational: its a very common agenda in criminal justice that the public doesnt want justice to cost more. The other was because theres a degree of freedom in being able to operate the way you need to, rather than conform to the really quite regimented funnels of how money is measured in terms of outcome."Fountain is happy with the success the business has achieved but is far from complacent. "I think its down at the end of the day to what we make," he says. "Artisan bread seems to be getting more popular. Theres always a place for bread like this in high-end restaurants like Pauls."However, over the last year I would say that weve been getting wholesale requests from customers that perhaps you wouldnt expect would want this product: you wouldnt expect them to be paying the premium for it. So I guess the market is growing, where everything  in bread is dramatically falling."With some bemusement he notes that a well-known Scottish bakery recently sold off its equipment. Its traditional bakery market had collapsed to the point where it made more sense to retool the premises so that it could make dog biscuits instead. "There is more money and more sustainability in making dog biscuits than there is in making bread," he observes.Some  prisoners or former prisoners have worked with the bakery. Ten of them have gone into employment, two of them have reoffended."To this day," says Fortune, "my experience of them is that every one is pretty dferent. Some of their problems are similar but everyone reacts in a dferent way and their experience of prison has been dferent as well."Of the four former current prisoners working at Freedom, theirof service ranges from one month to two-and-a-half years, "on and off. We have one guy whom we trained while he was in prison and was given a job as soon as he came out. He took a full-time job where and I asked him to come back - headhunted is too grandiose - because hes really good at his job. And come back he did."He modestly downplays the role played by the bakery when it comes to those prisoners who, through it, have found employment and started to rebuild their lives."At the end of the day, one of the things that I feel really passionate about is that people get places because they work at it. In our factory you have a great situation on the table that someone can take advantage of. Some people have thanked me but equally they would be thanking some of the other team-mates."Some of the best connections that people here make are with someone who has been through the prison system and is now working at the bakery, slightly further down the line. But what I would say about our team is that its incredibly strong, and very close-knit, but," he adds with a laugh, "are entirely a pack of strays as well."Fortune is equally modest on the subject of his own circumstances. "I basically havent done anything with my le. I was an eternal student and was offered a funded PhD at Oxford. I had quite severe cold feet about going onto that, so I stopped it and started to think about what someone like me could do."As it happens, I couldnt really get a job. Like quite a lot of people you look to charity work because you can see it as being fulfilling, and for my sins thats what I did. I realised after a little while that I wanted to do my own thing, I wanted to do some social enterprise, I wanted it to be in food, because Ive always been very interested in food. I think its a very social thing when youre making it for other people. The bare bones came from these impulses and instincts, and slowly it became a bakery idea."Though my experience of this world is quite short, I think there is genuinely more and more of an interest that businesses have some positive impact beyond their shareholders and their profit margins. And one of the things that I try to do ... is that we dont really market anything about our products as having anything to do with our social impact agendas, so much so that Ill go to a tasting with a potential customer and theyll have no idea that were a social enterprise."Rightly or wrongly, I quite like that, because it gives me the sense that people want our bread because they like it, and not because of the story. Therersquos dignity in it and dignity is what our people need to get their lives back on track."At the end of the day, well go nowherewe cant sell our bread. The idea is that we are masters of our own destiny, and in this sort of recession-post-recession and who knows whats happening with Brexit, thats really important."The head baker at Freedom, Scott MacKenzie, , has been with the operation since its earliest days in Low Moss. He started a matter of weeks after Fortune got permission to build a bakery there. "I did all the recipes and the menu and the training for all the guys."When we got the opportunity to set up the bakery the way I wanted it done, I designed it around a process that would be as simple as possible, to try and maintain consistency. That is the biggest goal for me."In his time he has worked alongside numerous former or current prisoners. "There are two sides to this," he says. "Not everyone wants to be a baker, long term, in their le. But when theyre in jail its a very surreal environment what the bakery does is create a normal working environment, where they all get treated equally. Eventhey dont go into baking, it helps them with team-work and communication. Ive seen some guys who have benefited from that, eventheyve not come on board after theyve got out of jail."Paul Tamburrini for one is full of praise for what is happening at the bakery. "What he is giving to those guys is just incredible," he says. "I cant speak highly enough of him as a person."The chef was impressed by what he saw when he posed for photographs at Freedom the other week. "Im hoping to take my kitchen staff back up there to see what they do," he adds. "Our head chef is going to spend three or four days there - not to pinch ideas or anything like that, but just to see all the aspects of it what theyre doing to help these young guys, how they make the bread ... I was blown away when I saw it. It is," he says again, "awesome."* www.freedombakery.org

title: climate-change-school-strikers-say-teachers-are-not-helping
story: Thousands of students have taken part in the global protests in recent weeks.Read more:Glasgow students stage third protest against climate changeNow some say that, although they were not being punished for skipping class, teachers have failed to provide catch-up resources when asked.Speaking to the Scottish Greens Spring Conference on Sudnay, protester Holly Gillibrand, , said: "Our headteacher is really supportive."But a lot of the teachers, especially those who teach on Friday afternoons, are not supportive at all."Because weve been given permission from our parents and the council, they cant do anything directly."Read more:Students campaign worldwide for action on climate changeShe added: "Theyve been doing things to basically spite us."The Educational Institute for Scotland union said that it was "unreasonable" for students to expect special arrangements.Larry Flanagan, general secretary of the EIS teaching union, said: "If the bulk of the pupils are in the class and the teacher is teaching them then it would be totally impractical for schools to take a period out of the following week to revise what one or two pupils missed."Schools dont have the capacity anyway and the rest of the class would just be marking time.Read more:Pupils will not be punished for climate change strikes"At this time of the year teachers are particularly stretched because they will be working flat out to get pupils ready for exams."If there are class hand-outs or homework tasks that have been set then they would be passed on, just asa pupil were absent through illness, and they could do those at home."However, it is unreasonable to expect special arrangements to be made for a handful of pupils who have missed whole lessons."

title: jeremy-corbyn-tells-pm-to-abandon-brexit-red-lines
story: The Labour leader said it is "scandalous" the Prime Minister did not seek dialogue with Labour on Brexit earlier.Mr Corbyn said Mrs May should not use the delay of Brexit until October  as a chance to put her Withdrawal Agreement to the Commons again.Read more:Ministers to hold more talks with Labour to end Brexit impasseReferring to the talks between the Government and Labour, Mr Corbyn said: "Its scandalous that it came so late in the Brexit process, not at the eleventh hour, not even at five to midnight, but at five past midnight after she missed her own deadline of the th of March."Nevertheless, were engaging in the talks in a serious and constructive way."But we must see those red lines moving and we must see real compromise."And I have to say, it is a challenge to negotiate with a Government thats collapsing - when you cant be surecommitments made by the Prime Minister will survive the week and when Cabinet collective responsibility has given way to collective irresponsibility, with ministers contradicting each other on the airwaves.Read more:Nicola Sturgeon to outline Indyref plans within days"Nearly everyone now agrees that the Prime Minister could and should have tried to build a consensus much earlier."Mr Corbyn was scathing about how the Prime Minister had handled Brexit.Speaking at the Welsh Labour conference, Mr Corbyn said: "Just three weeks ago she said she wasnt prepared to delay Brexit beyond the th of June."But now were holding European elections, not knowing whether MEPs will take their seats or for how long.
